Diana,

When I was growing up the "Gold Standard" in "Classroom Management" was a short Italian Nun with an American made hardwood yardstick! There were no problems with classroom behavior and academic standards were high. In fact most everyone learned a second language as well as some Latin.

Going back to those "good old days" would be too much of a shock for most today, but it does point out that being in control of the classroom, by whatever means is the first requirement in teaching and the first place the public school system fails in all too many cases today and for the past generation or two!

I know teachers have been talking about classroom management for a long time, because when I was involved with local committee work years ago it came up a lot, so I am wondering why it is not given appropriate attention in teacher training programs.  It's a great skill set to have, it seems to me.  I was really impressed when I encountered how a teacher in a high school one of my son's attended used Collaborative Problem Solving, for example.  So I would place high value on expertise in classroom management.  Which, of course, is not to not place a high value on expertise in content areas, too.

First, you presume that this approach is the only or most effective way to fight terrorism. It is more likely that it is the worst and most expensive, but it is expedient because every step in the process, from authorization and budgeting to secret court decisions, have been made by insiders spending our money.

Second, your ignorance of what can be done with metadata to discover facts about every single one of us is abundant.

I have personally spied with metadata very successfully -- with the willing, signed authorization of the spied upon. And using metadata only, I won more than a dozen copyright cases against corporate copyright thieves who had signed my licensing agreement. I never knew the name of a single individual who had unlawfully read our copyrighted content -- only the metadata that someone had received it, and which licensee had originally licensed it.

And not one lawyer for any of the big corporations caught by my tiny, three-person company ever thought to challenge the data I'd collected. They all paid. The fact that Person A contacted Person B -- the metadata -- is 90% of the data; what they subsequently said is predictable.

I would like an explanation of how the quantity of "20 millions words" was arrived at.  While I agree that language and vocabulary are vitally important, there are not 20 million words in the entire English language.  This statement is misleading.

"the protesters are.trying to figure out a way of getting rid of the anti-democratic Thaksin for good".
Simple and democratic: convince the electorate that they are less corrupt:
offer it a credible and better alternative and win the next election.
Their past and current programs of military coups,rigged courts
and the dictatorship of a "people"s" council are not going to win the hearts
and minds, nor the votes, of the majority.

The premise of this article is fundamentally wrong. The protestors are not anti-democratic, they are anti-Thaksin and everyone who lives in Thailand knows Thaksin is still calling all the shots, Yinkluck is just his proxy.

And Thanksin is the more corrupt and anti-democratic political leader is modern Thai history. During his term as PM he dis-mantled several democratic institutions had some 2,500 suspected drug dealers murdered, limited freedom of the press, and tried to control the courts.

So the protesters know that Thaksin has won the support of the uneducated masses who love him for his handouts and don't really understand any of the other issues. Another election will most certainly be won again by the current Thaksin led government. The protestors are not anti-democratic, they are trying to figure out a way of getting rid of the anti-democratic Thaksin for good.

If you are going to write "news analysis", you should dig deeper into the cause of this protest event.  In the beginning it did not have intention to expell this goverment even though we know it is badly corrupted and is under actual control by Mr.Thaksin.  The protesters began to come out after this government passed the amnasty bill (at 4 AM, it should be noted) which will virtually get rid of all criminal charges of everyone, including Mr.Thaksin, since 2004. If this bill takes effect, Mr.Thaksin, who is a fleeing fugitive right now, can walk right back to Thailand without any charges.  Now, is that democracy?  If the ruling of the court can be overturned by the government or the parliament, then why have the court at all?  Democracy should be the balance of power of the three pillars : Judiciary (court), legislature (parliament), and executive (government), and any attempt to interfere with this balance of power should be considered "anti-democracy" as you called it, and Yinglak's government had done just that.  In addition, Phue Thai's MPs also announced that they will not accept the ruling of constitutional court.  By saying that, they should not be considered to be part of democracy system any more.  What the protesters want is for this government to resign completely, then we will reform the political system and try to reinstate the balance of power.  Once the system is corrected, election will be held.

You ask "Does the author really know why they are against this upcoming election??"
You don't have to be very professional to realize it's because they
know they will lose this election,, as they have all five previous ones against Thaksin parties.
Will the demonstrators and the DP ever accept the simple fact that
Thaksin parties are genuinely popular and that they will have to share some of "their" cake with the rural masses?

Before writing any article better do some serious research on the matters.  I wondered whether the author has really been studied about the demanding of the demonstrators at all??  Does the author really know why they are against this upcoming election?? and their plans to improve democracy in this country?? Any movements and goals they are pursuing are still under constitution law. They might violated some petty offences such as traffic regulations, etc.  Be professional pls

If you understand pharmacology and statistics you can actually ask sensible questions and evaluate if their medicine will be helpful. But no, most American docs are in no position to resist the smiles of the pretty girl because they have not been taught how to.

There is a natural interaction and relationship between pharmacology and medicine. Of course some doctors will work for pharmacology companies; they need to do drug trials, that involves doctors, should the doctors work for free?

The Times readers love to bash medicine; they should post their jobs and let us find fault with their industry for a change.

Incorrect. Medicare is NOT compelled to pay for any or all drugs as long as a licensed doctor prescribes them.  It pays for generic drug alternatives if there is one and denies the brand names, as it should

MJ,
If the doctor fills in the box DAW (Dispense As Written) Medicare is obligated to pay for it.

Great news.

Just a few years ago drug companies were not only paying doctors 'cash' to speak on their behalf, but also rewarded them with Limousine rides to Yankee games, Cruises, week-ends at a spa, etc., for writing prescriptions. The is now illegal.

But we have a long way to go. There is so much corruption in this 'game' that I don't even know where to start.

Propublica has been doing a great job exposing drug companies for some time now.
http://projects.propublica.org/docdollars/ Check this website about your own doctors, or those you know. Some of them know no shame. Most doctors are honorable, but quite a large number are not.

More irksome is the fact that our Government prohibits Medicare from negotiating prices with the drug makers. A Government mandated prohibition against negotiating prices between buyers and sellers. Imagine that!

Medicare is compelled by law to pay for any and all drugs, whether effective or not, whether alternatives are available or not, as long as a licensed doctor prescribes them.

Think about what's going on here.

Is this 'free-market', as we understand the term?
The cost of drugs today is driven by "kickbacks" to physicians? Where do you get this information? R&D is phenomenally expensive.

Congratulations to SKB for this new policy.  As one who has seen these payment schemes in action for years - as a second-string observer, the practice is worse than disgusting.  Performance based (read: sales) payments to prescribing providers is a horrible practice and more than one of them play otherwise equal drugs one against the other.  While in practice, these payments appear in many different forms, their objective is always the same:  Sell more of our drug, encourage others to sell our drug and we will reward you generously.  Let the drug's facts and efficacy speak for themselves and the prescribing providers order medication based ONLY on what is the best choice for each individual patient.  Yes folks, some annual payments to some medical providers, both in cash and in-kind compensation can reach hundreds of dollars or more.  Do YOU want your doctor making your medication choices based upon the 'rewards' that he expects from a drug company?  Today's high cost of medications is not to support the R&D labs, but to pay kickbacks to cooperative doctors.  Accepting these payments or other compensation should be made a federal felony, one with prison time attached.
